head.supplied: Mogo ¶ 16/8/90. ¶ ¶ […] ¶ ¶ In reference to the bark sent from here some time ago, under the name Acacia longifolia, […] Being however not positively sure about it, I sent specimens of it to Baron v...

div.p: From Wilhelm Bäuerlen to Joseph Maiden
MRS 203/2, Inwards correspondence — special bundles, 1886-1921, 90/533, Archives of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney

In reference to the bark sent from here some time ago, under the name Acacia longifolia, […] Being however not positively sure about it, I sent specimens of it to Baron von Muller, who determined it to be Ac. linifolia , […]

You will perhaps remember that about two years ago, I sent a log, bark etc, from Cambewarra, supposing it to be a hybrid between Euc. corymbosa and Euc. maculata, to which view Baron von Muller at the time also felt inclined in judging from flowering specimens and empty fruit capsules. A few days ago,I found another tree of much larger size, of which I obtained a log, some kino, and flowering and fruiting specimens. […] The Hybrid is in full flower and E. corymbosa has flowered off, and just as with the tree at Cambewarra, in spite of its heavy flowering, there was scarcely any fruit; […] I obtained only 15 capsules, and I am sure I missed none, but they are all closed and no doubt contain seed, which will help to determine whether the tree is a Hybrid or a distinct species, as I have flowering and fruiting specimens, both for the Museum and Baron von Muller. […]
